Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Solid-State Properties of Phosphine Coordination Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Summary
This project involves the preparation of a new family of crystalline porous materials that display desirable properties, which can be exploited in a range of applications relating to energy and the environment. Porous materials are of critical importance in many large-scale processes, such as water purification, the separation and purification of gases, polymer synthesis, environmental protection by trapping of toxic chemicals in waste streams, and many others. It is important to explore the synthesis of new porous materials that can be designed to offer enhanced properties. With support of the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, the major goals of this research activity directly relate to this challenge, and include the synthesis and application testing of new materials that incorporate previously unexplored chemical functionalities. This project incorporates a new and innovative international student exchange program, which is aimed at inspiring undergraduate students to become engaged in research-based studies. The program also provides students a unique and invaluable opportunity to become fully acquainted with the culture of international collaboration in the sciences, through a period of study abroad at one of several outstanding partner universities across the globe.

Technical Summary
The goals of this research activity involve the preparation of a new family of metal-organic framework (MOF) materials, using a specific synthetic strategy that provides access to materials with previously inaccessible chemical reactivity. MOFs are crystalline, polymeric solids that contain precise molecular architectures and exhibit inter-connected networks of small pores (0.5-5.0 nm), which are accessible to a broad range of 'guest' adsorbates. MOFs have already shown great promise as materials for high capacity gas storage, and for sequestration of small molecules and other species such as heavy metal ions. Their broad applicability is derived from extreme design flexibility, as a function of the components used in their preparation. The Humphrey group has established synthetic approaches to prepare MOFs based on tailored organophosphine and metallic complexes based on phosphine ligands. Phosphine-based complexes are important as reactive catalytic species that can induce small molecule activation; it is therefore of timely interest to incorporate such reactivity into MOF-type materials. In this project, phosphine complexes with well-defined open (unsaturated) metal sites are first synthesized and then used to construct porous MOFs. Subsequently, these materials are studied under a range of conditions to assess the binding and selective sequestration behavior toward guest species of direct relevance to future energy applications, and for molecular sensing. The project is ideally suited to teach young researchers a range of skills from molecular synthesis to solid-state materials chemistry and characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grant number DMR-1506694 supported fundamental research in the Humphrey labs at the Department of Chemistry, University of Texas at Austin.  The grant supported the doctoral studies of six graduate students, three of whom successfully graduated with Ph.D. degrees, as well as one M.S. student.  The grant also directly supported hands-on research and study abroad experiences for a large (>15) cohort of undergraduate scholars from U.T. Austin and from overseas, as part of our innovative AIF undergraduate exchange program, which was conceived, initiated and developed thanks to this grant (see below).

 

The research goals of this project were to design, discover and study new porous materials based on the use of a specific family of organic building blocks, known as phosphines.  Phosphines are commonly used in industrial homogeneous catalysis and they provide vital functions in the synthesis of complex molecules, including pharmaceuticals.  Our aims are to find ways to translate such properties into a topical class of materials, known as metal-organic frameworks (or MOFs).  Through our work over a period of nearly 4 years, we have achieved a number of diverse research outcomes from this project, which not only met our initial goals, but also exceeded expectations in two ways.  1). We now understand how to assemble phosphines into MOFs with precise architectures that can be exploited to generate new catalyst materials in a rational sense.  This progress has opened-up a large number of new possibilities for the preparation of materials with applicable functions.  2).  We discovered and developed a particular MOF based on phosphines that acts as a sensor for a range of trace contaminants by a visual detection method.  The sensor materials can be deployed on paper as disposable test strip for the instantaneous sensing of contaminants in water and in fuels that cannot otherwise be detected remotely.  This discovery was patented at U.T. Austin and has resulted in the formation of a startup company called Lantha, Inc., which now employs U.T. Austin graduate students and also offers undergraduate internships.

 

The broader impacts of this project are deep and will have a meaningful impact on a large number of undergraduate students for many years to come.  Through DMR-1506694, the PI launched an innovative new undergraduate international exchange program called the Austin-International Framework (AIF), which enables scholars from U.T. Austin and from several partner institutions around the globe to spend a semester abroad.  The program is innovative in three important ways: 1). Through NSF-DMR and alumni donor support, we provide each student with a scholarship to ensure that students from all financial backgrounds can participate.  2).  We partner with universities of international acclaim and with whom we share institutional agreements that ensures all students still pay home tuition rates and are eligible for regular student aid.  3). Each student not only engages in study abroad but also gains credit for engaging in research in the labs of internationally renowned researchers.  The short- and long-term benefits of this program for each student are numerous and greatly enhances the future career prospects of the participants.  There are also tangible benefits of this program for the participating institutions, as the AIF provides a conduit for advancements in scientific collaboration.  In only 4 years, the AIF model has gained recognition to the extent that we are now expanding the program across the entire College of Natural Sciences at U.T. Austin.  This will not only ensure longevity of the program but will enable hundreds of students to benefit per year.
